 Station Grays Harbor Tower Rehabilitation
 The tower is starting to show wear from exposure to high winds and continuous salt air exposure. The side paneling has holes, random areas are boarded over from past damage. The corner trim and fascia are rotted on the west facing side. The door framing is damaged. The structure is roughly 10x10x8 and the roof is 14x11 flat rolled asphalt. Tower is 75' feet tall. Repair is needed soon as possible to prevent further wind and rain damage to the structure and equipment.  
 
 Work will include removal of existing exterior trim ,siding, fascia and roof flashing. The windows may need to be temporarily removed to facilitate siding replacement. A CFR will need to be initiated once the siding is removed based upon the internal condition of the walls. Windows should be replaced depending on condition. The exterior should be painted with a high quality paint able to withstand the unique weather at this location. Total estimated cost $7500.00.   
 See attached pictures.

NAICS: 237990 - Other Heavy and Civil Engineering Construction
Description:
Bundling PSN 11729947 and 13913550 under one design and contracting package.
 
 Repair HVAC Bldg D
 
 The exhaust fans in the galley kitchen run at all times whether or not food is being prepared. There are no fan controls in the galley and the kitchen staff cannot turn them off at the end of the day. Having these fans run during off hours not only wastes fan energy but also ejects conditioned air from the space, which increases the cooling and heating loads of the RTUs. This project will replace the two exhaust fans with one large fan controlled by a VFD to adjust flow based on the amount of smoke and heat from cooking. This will reduce the flow for much of the day and turn off the fans at night.

Likely demolition method to include saw-cutting sections from top down and removing to barge using barge crane. Contractor will need to be cognizant of over water work and containment of concrete sections, dust. The lighthouse will not be replaced in kind.
 
 Safety: 5 Decrepit structure well past its service life. Intense spalling, rebar failure, column failure, and unsafe access have proven the structure to be useless in maintaining an optic.
 Mission Impact: 3 The ANT cannot access the light on the lighthouse, so a temporary light is in place. The lighthouse obscures 15 degrees of the temporary light marking the channel for mariners.
 Environmental: 2 Large falling sections of spalled concrete could fall into water surrounding lighthouse.
 Political Visibility: 2 Lighthouse is seen and known by the City.
 Executability: 2 Potential roadblock includes environmental approval due to jetty being surrounded by water. However, jetty will remain in place and contractors will be required to follow best management practices.

Our facility has an existing sight-screen precast prestressed concrete panel wall
 on the north and west perimeters. The west section of the wall is approximately 201’ long and
 consists of twenty-two (22) panels, each approximately 8’ wide, 11’ tall (3’ below grade), and 4”
 thick, and one 5’ gate opening with a chain link gate. The entire length of the west section is
 topped by three (3) strands of twelve (12) gauge twisted aluminized steel line wires with No. 14
 gage aluminum four (4) point barbs spaced not more than 4” apart. The scope of work will
 consist of replacing the existing sight-screen precast prestressed concrete panel wall, in whole
 or in part, on the west side of the facility with precast reinforced concrete panel wall and
 adding K12 bollards spaced approximately 3’ feet on center along the west perimeter.
 The intention of this SOW is to comply with American Concrete Institute (ACI) PRC-533-11 Guide
 for Precast Concrete Wall Panels (“ACI PRC-533-11”) and result in a perimeter wall that meets or
 exceeds the aesthetics and structural strength of the existing wall.

The contractor shall provide all personnel, supervision, and other items and services necessary to operate the water treatment and wastewater treatment plant in accordance with the Federal Regulations, Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ), and Texas Department of Health regulations.  This performance-based contract is to operate the water and wastewater treatment plant system at full operation during an eight-hour shift, seven days a week, including weekends and holidays. The contractor is to ensure the equipment is fully operational and in good condition and all water and wastewater systems meet applicable state and federal codes. The Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR), headed by an Associate Director, is responsible for ensuring compliance with all the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) wide programs and policies relating to corruption, misconduct, and for executing internal security, integrity, and background investigations.  
 
 To align ICE with other federal Law Enforcement (LE) agencies, the additional requirement of completing and passing a polygraph examination was included during the hiring process for applicants of entry level LE positions.  In 2016, ICE OPR established the Credibility Assessment Operations Unit (CAOU) to oversee the administering of the polygraph program.  The primary mission of the CAOU is to enhance and maintain the integrity of the ICE workforce by means of an accredited polygraph examination credibility assessment process.  CAOU anticipates applicant polygraph testing to begin in the second quarter of Fiscal Year (FY) 2018.
 
 CAOU needs a Polygraph Case Management System (PCMS) that allows CAOU management and polygraph examiners the ability to efficiently and effectively collect and review all required information necessary to initiate, schedule, prepare for, execute, conduct, review, complete CAOU polygraph examinations, and report findings to management.
 
 CAOU seeks to optimize and enhance its mission through the introduction of services with expertise in application design, project management, database engineering, data mapping, and analysis.
 
 The scope of work for the PCMS project is to implement and maintain a custom-developed solution to support CAOU mission requirements. The ICE PCMS solution shall be a commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) and must be based upon the architecture, technology, and source code of the PCMS solution developed for and used by Customs and Border Patrol (CBP). The Government shall have full ownership of the solution’s data rights and licenses.  The solution must be of a modular design that allows ICE the flexibility to add future functionality and applications, if the need arises. The Contractor shall provide program management support and software development subject matter experts to strategically plan and guide CAOU in gathering programmatic requirements, outlining design concepts, virtually engineering a business-case application, and providing training and maintenance. The Contractor shall also provide to ICE advice on CAOU processes, assess data inputs and outputs, correlate data relationships, integrate program activities, and provide operational changes to either restructure or improve CAOU’s business model.  
 
 The Contractor shall comply with all ICE charters, policies, procedures and plans, processes, manuals, models, and guides. The Contractor shall comply with any changes to the ICE IT program made during the task order period of performance. 
 
 Unless explicitly specified, the Contractor is responsible for delivering the implementation and Operations and Maintenance (O&M) aspects of this task order as Firm Fixed-Price (FFP) and optional Surge tasks as Labor Hours (LH).

The Government has a requirement for needing an estimated 14,400 rooms for the time period of October 2022, through December 2022, for lodging students Off Center due to dorm rooms on Center being at capacity.  This number is not all inclusive.  This number is subject to change based on class changes and cancellations.    The number is total rooms and will be broken down by class.  At this time the Government does not know the specific arrival dates or departure dates because classes are still registering.  Specific classes with number of students, arrival dates, and departure dates has not been finalized. Classes will arrive at different dates though out the months of October 2022, through December 2022.  Rooms will be ordered for the number of students in one (1) class.  Thus, multiple awards are expected.  Classes range from 24 students to 48 students; however, may be smaller or larger than 24 or 48.  The classes will be arriving and departing at different times.  For example, there may be two (2) classes of 24 students arriving on 4/7/18 and departing on 4/12/18; four classes of 24 to 48 students arriving on 4/7/18 and departing on 4/13/18; and then six classes of 24 to 48 students arriving on 4/14/18 and departing on 4/27/18.

NAICS: 561611 - Investigation and Personal Background Check Services
Description: The purpose of this requirement is to obtain Contractor support to assist the Deputy Commandant for Mission Support (DCMS-34) Office of Security Policy and Management in fulfillment of the requirements for the Coast Guard's implementation of deploying the TASS program, or such system that may replace the TASS program.  The Contractor shall act as the Coast Guard’s Service Point of Contact (SPOC); shall provide documentation support to DCMS-34; shall provide data management services; shall provide training support by assisting DCMS-34 in assessing inadequate processes and procedures at local Trusted Agent Security Managers (TASM) Sites, providing guidance to TASM sites through the use of informal training, discussions, lessons-learned, and Q&A sessions.  In accordance with the tenets of Homeland Security Presidential Directive 12 (HSPD-12), all USCG contractor employment and identity information must be entered into an authoritative system such as the TASS before a CAC can be authorized. This requirement applies to all military, civilian, and contractor employees who require unescorted access to federally-controlled facilities and federally-controlled Information Technology (IT) systems.

NAICS: 237110 - Water and Sewer Line and Related Structures Construction
Description:
Repair or replace Clarifier components, replace Clarifier Gearbox/Motor Assemblies and Controls for an operable wastewater treatment facility.  Furnish all labor, tools, materials, permits, and supervision in accordance with Manufacturer’s instructions to repair the clarifiers, re-work the structures, and replace the drive units and controls as stated below:
 Both Clarifier drive units and controls shall be interchangeable.
 Clarifier #1 and #2:
 •	Remove the existing drive units and retain for owner, ensure no materials fall into the clarifier. 
 •	Modify the mounting structures, as needed, to accommodate the new drive units
 •	Inspect the existing density current baffles, rake arms, feed wells, skimmer arms, and all associated structures and repair or replace for a secure operating system
 •	Remove the existing motor controls/disconnects and discard
 •	Install new NEMA 4X Stainless motor controls/disconnects, sized for the new drive units, in a new location just off the clarifier walkways. These are Class 1 Division 2 areas and the controls/disconnects shall be install as per the NFPA 70 standards for the classification. 
 •	 Install new drive units, minimum .75hp, 3 phase, 208 volts, 60hz, and connect to the new controls/disconnects using a conduit seal at the exit of the controls/disconnects and RMC conduit to the drive units. Metal re-enforced Liquid-Tight conduit shall be used to connect from the RMC to the drive unit motors, maximum 3’ length. Liquid-Tight fittings must be rated for a Class 1 Division 1 area as per NFPA 70.
 •	Install wiring and connect as per NFPA 70 standards
 •	Test the new drive units for a minimum of 24 hours and correct any issues that may arise.

Furnish all labor, tools, materials, permits, and supervision in accordance with Manufacturer’s instructions for installation of motorized roll-up hurricane protection shutters for the windows and doors.  The Contractor shall provide motorized Category 5 roll-up hurricane protection shutters to all window openings, provide removable shutters for the entrance/exit doors and elevator glass door entrance, include electrical installation/operation with controls from inside the building, and use the existing window/door frame to install each shutter and avoid any damages to the structure. The Contractor shall seek the recommendation of a structural engineer to ensure appropriate shutter installation.
